comments.body: Dropping the `BinaryWriter` seems like a pretty big change.  Can you provide some more details on why that was appropriate?

It was a mistake by me, it was the `this` argument that you pass as first argument to `.call()`. Now, it reflects the interface of all the `writeInt32`, `writeString`, `writeBytes`, etc. methods in class `BinaryWriter`. All of them expect two arguments, the field number and the value.
Thanks for clarifying!  As you say, it's good to write tests. :smile:

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +196,200 @@    fieldNumber: number,
    writer: BinaryWriter,
    keyWriterFn: (field: number, key: K) => void,
    valueWriterFn: (field: number, value: V, writerCallback: BinaryWriteCallback) => void,
    writeCallback?: BinaryWriteCallback

comments.body: Without knowing anything about this API, I would have guessed that "defaultValue" was the correct name, since it seems odd to pass a value to a value reader.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +204,208 @@    reader: BinaryReader,
    keyReaderFn: (reader: BinaryReader) => K,
    valueReaderFn: (reader: BinaryReader, value: any, readerCallback: BinaryReadCallback) => V,
    readCallback?: BinaryReadCallback,
    defaultKey?: K,
